title: In Star Trek, why can they use the transporter on people but they can't replicate living biological material? - Quora
tags: Star Trek: Deep Space Nine (TV Series)
Star Trek: The Next Generation (TV series)

response.answer_text: It’s never really been explained on screen, but according to official Star Trek reference volumes, the replicators do not have sufficient resolution for the task - neither, for the record, do cargo transporters without modifications. Replicators and cargo transporters work on molecular-level resolution. Personnel transporters work on the subatomic or quantum level. In order to get around certain limitations of quantum physics, personnel transporters use components called Heisenberg compensators which are sometimes referenced in technobabble on the show. You may, quite justifiably, wonder why don’t they just install Heisenberg compensators on replicators and replicate living matter. This, too, has never been explained, and in fact we have seen transporters successfully replicate rather than merely transport living beings, so it doesn’t appear to be a technical limitation. In the TNG episode Second Chances, the Enterprise returned to a planet where Commander Riker had undertaken a difficult mission as a Starfleet lieutenant, and discovered that a transporter accident had created a second Lieutenant Riker who remained on the surface for the next eight years. After his rescue, this second Riker, who chose to go by “Thomas,” transferred to another ship before ultimately betraying Starfleet and joining the Maquis. This may give us part of our answer: replicating sapient beings could lead to identity theft and other security issues. But the other part, to my mind, is largely this: the Federation is extremely paranoid when it comes to cloning and genetic manipulation. Genetic engineering is forbidden except to correct life-threatening defects (this is why Deep Space Nine’s Dr. Julian Bashir nearly had to resign when it was discovered his parents had subjected him to eugenic treatment), and cloning appears to be similarly forbidden. The Federation doesn’t even appear to use cloned organs in medical treatment much, if at all, instead relying on cybernetic implants such as Captain Picard’s heart and Geordi LaForge’s visor. Thus, it is very likely that the Federation explicitly forbids experimentation with transporters and replicators to duplicate living tissue. It is entirely possible that other cultures have engaged in such experimentation, but we have yet to see it on screen.

The key part of the explanation in not technological, but practical storytelling.  A Star Trek writer working on reasons why the transporters and replicators work for a small number of sharply-defined purposes, but why they can’t be used for purposes that would ruin the story. If you could use the transporter to (for example) store a person’s patterns for decades (using whatever method Scotty used to keep his own from breaking down), then why couldn’t you “bring back the dead” by dematerialising the last stored copy of someone who had been killed or simply died of old age? Why couldn’t you have eternal youth by periodically resetting the flesh to an earlier state? (Remember they restored a nearly dead Doctor Pulaski using the transporter and she even retained her memories of events up to the moment of the procedure; TNG second-season episode “Unnatural Selection”.) Why couldn’t you take your best soldiers and scientists and replicate hundreds of thousands of them and go on berserk wars of conquest - against enemies who would no doubt start doing the same thing, resulting in a new kind of war? (An even faster version of the Dominion’s production methods of Jem’Hadar soldiers, whose military skills appear to be part of their genetic code.) The problem with inventing future technology is that you also have to account for all the implications. In the case of the Star Trek transporter and replicator technology, the writers have to do handsprings to explain away why such things as I list above are just not possible, or at least not practical. But it’s okay, I have reconciled myself to the fact that even if someone invents lightsabers like on Star Wars, they will never allow me to own a “lightsaber riding lawnmower,” a “lightsaber electric shaver,” or a “lightsaber bug zapper.” (Maybe a lightsaber cordless drill? Can those things do corkscrews?) That’s writers for you - they want their cake, but they lick off the icing before you get any!
